importantDates.descriptionOfWhyDateIsRelevant: Diwali is celebrated on this date in the autumn, marking the beginning of the festival's five-day observance, which includes key religious and cultural traditions.
Sikhs celebrate Bandi Chhor Divas on this date, marking the liberation of Guru Hargobind and 52 Hindu kings from imprisonment, a pivotal moment in Sikh history.

importantTimeframes.descriptionOfWhyTimeFrameIsRelevant: The five-day Diwali festival spans from Dhanteras to Bhai Dooj, forming a cultural and spiritual time period of renewal, family gathering, and religious observance across South Asia and diasporas.

keyTakeAways: Diwali is a major festival celebrated by over a billion Hindus, Sikhs, Jains, and Buddhists globally, symbolizing the triumph of light over darkness and good over evil.
The festival is observed on October 20, 2025, and lasts five days with distinct daily rituals: Dhanteras, Choti Diwali, Diwali (Lakshmi Puja), Padwa, and Bhai Dooj.

Each day has specific traditions: Dhanteras involves buying gold and cleaning homes for prosperity; Choti Diwali celebrates Lord Krishna's victory over Narakasura; Diwali marks Lakshmi worship and family gatherings; Padwa honors marital bonds; Bhai Dooj celebrates sibling love.
For Sikhs, Diwali is observed as Bandi Chhor Divas, commemorating the release of Guru Hargobind and 52 kings from imprisonment, highlighting themes of justice and liberation.
For Jains, Diwali marks the attainment of enlightenment by Lord Mahavira; for Buddhists, it signifies Emperor Ashoka’s embrace of Buddhism.
Diwali transcends religion and has become a cultural festival celebrated by people of many faiths and none, emphasizing community, family, and renewal.
The festival marks the start of the new Hindu financial year, with businesses opening new accounts and gambling (in some regions) considered auspicious due to a legend involving Shiva and Parvati.

summaryOfNewsArticle: Diwali, the festival of lights, is celebrated globally by over a billion Hindus, Sikhs, Jains, and Buddhists on October 20, 2025, marking the triumph of light over darkness and good over evil. The five-day festival includes distinct traditions: Dhanteras (buying gold, cleaning homes), Choti Diwali (Krishna’s victory over Narakasura), Diwali (Lakshmi Puja and family gatherings), Padwa (marital bonds and Govardhan Hill story), and Bhai Dooj (sibling love). For Sikhs, Diwali is observed as Bandi Chhor Divas, commemorating the liberation of Guru Hargobind and 52 kings from imprisonment. For Jains, it marks the enlightenment of Lord Mahavira, and for Buddhists, the conversion of Emperor Ashoka. The festival also signifies the start of a new financial year and is celebrated culturally beyond religious boundaries, emphasizing community, renewal, and shared values.
title: It’s Diwali, a time for light, community and fresh starts
